facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 98 and 99 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 98 and 99 of 1960. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 16, 1958, and April 11, 1958, of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order and decree Nos. 173 and 151 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 16, 1958, and April 11, 1958, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order and decree Nos. 173 and 151 of 1957, respectively.

facts.text: Appellants own a Jute Mill at Calcutta and carry on the business of manufacture and sale of Jute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are that the appellants own a Jute Mill at Calcutta and carry on the business of manufacture and sale of Jute.

facts.text: On September 7, 1955 appellants entered into a contract with respondents for purchase of 750 bales of Jute cutting raw of Pakistan at Rs. 80 per bale of 400 lbs. to be delivered in October, November and December at 250 bales every month.

anchor.surface_text: On September 7, 1955 they entered into a companytract with the respondents who are doing business as dealers in jute, for the purchase of 750 bales of Jute cutting raw  of Pakistan at Rs. 80 per bale of 400 lbs. to be delivered in October, November and December at the rate of 250 belles every month.

facts.text: Clause 14 of the agreement provides that all disputes arising out of or concerning the contract should be referred to arbitration of Bengal Chamber of Commerce.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 14 of the agreement provides that all disputes arising out of or companycerning the companytract should be referred to the arbitration of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce.

facts.text: Respondents failed to deliver the goods as agreed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents failed to deliver the goods as agreed whereupon the appellants applied to the Bengal Chamber of Commerce for arbitration in accordance with el. 14 of the agreement.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Bengal Chamber of Commerce for arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: whereupon the appellants applied to the Bengal Chamber of Commerce for arbitration in accordance with el. 14 of the agreement.

facts.text: Respondents appeared before arbitrators and contested the claim on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents appeared before the arbitrators, and companytested the claim on the merits.

facts.text: Arbitrators made award in favour of appellants for Rs. 41,250 with interest.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrators made an award in favour of the appellants for Rs. 41,250 with interest, and that was filed under s. 14  2  of the Indian Arbitration Act

facts.text: Award filed under s.14 of Indian Arbitration Act in Calcutta High Court original side, notice issued to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: and that was filed under s. 14  2  of the Indian Arbitration Act in the High Court of Calcutta in its original side and numberice was issued to the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents filed application in High Court under s.33 Arbitration Act praying declaration that contract dated September 7, 1955 illegal as contravening notification dated October 29, 1953, and award void.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondents filed an application in the High Court, presumably under s. 33 of the arbitration Act, wherein they prayed for a declaration that the companytract dated September 7, 1955, was illegal, as it was in companytravention of the numberification of the Central Government dated October 29, 1953, and that in companysequence proceedings taken thereunder before the Chamber of Commerce and the award in which they resulted were all void.

facts.text: Learned judge on original side dismissed respondents' application and passed decree in terms of award.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge on the original side before whom the application came up for hearing dismissed it, and passed a decree in terms of the award.

facts.text: Respondents preferred appeals to Division Bench of High Court, Appeals Nos. 173 and 151 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Against both this judgment and order, the respondents preferred appeals to a Division Bench of the High Court, Appeals Nos. 154 and 173 of 1957.

facts.text: Division Bench (Chakravartti C.J. and Lahiri J.) held contract illegal, allowed appeals, set aside award.

anchor.surface_text: They were heard by Chakravartti, C. J., and Lahari, J., who hold that the companytract dated September 7, 1955, was illegal as it fell within the prohibition of the numberification aforesaid and accordingly allowed the appeal and set aside the award.

facts.text: Appellants applied for certificate under Art. 133(1) of Constitution, which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for a certificate under Art. 133  1  of the Constitution and the same was granted.

facts.text: Central Government notification dated October 29, 1953 under s.17 Forward Contracts Regulation Act prohibiting forward contracts other than non-transferable specific delivery contracts for raw jute.

anchor.surface_text: Such a numberification was issued by the Central Government in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 17 of the Act, on October 29, 1953. It is as follows - No. 2 24  Jute/53-In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 17 of the Forward Contracts  Regulation  Act, 1952  LXXIV of 1952 , the Central Government hereby declares that numberperson shall enter into any forward companytract other than a numbertransferable specific delivery companytract for the sale or purchase of raw jute in any form

facts.text: No dispute that contract is a specific delivery contract.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute between the parties that it is a specific delivery companytract.

facts.text: Appellants held import licences No. A 062290/52 and A 063733/52 from Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: During the period of the companytract with which we are companycerned the appellants held two import licences from the Government of India  1  No. A 062290/52 and  2  A 063733/52.

facts.text: Licences non-transferable, for actual user, goods to be utilised in licence holder's factory, not sold.

anchor.surface_text: Valid at any Indian Port .  Not transferable except under a letter of authority from the authority who issued the licences or from any Import Trade Controller . ... This licence is issued subject to the companydition that the goods will be utilised only for companysumption as raw material or accessories in the licence bolders factory and that numberportion thereof will be hold to any party.

facts.text: On September 26, 1955, appellants wrote to Joint Chief Controller for letter of authority in favour of sellers for 2,500 maunds jute cuttings.

anchor.surface_text: On September 26, 1955, acting under licence No, A 062290/52 the appellants wrote to the Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports, Government of India, to issue a letter of authority in favour of sellers Messrs. Raymon Company  India  Ltd., for 2,500 maunds jute cuttings

facts.text: Letter of authority received September 29, 1955? (text says 1956, likely typo), sent to respondents for Contract No. 2306, 1250 Mds.

anchor.surface_text: The letter of authority was received by the appellants on September 29, 1956, and they sent it on to the respondents with the following letter Dear Sirs, Contract No. 2306 We are sending. here with the Exchange Control Copy of Letter of Authority for 1250 Mds. Jute cuttings against the above.

facts.text: Contract No. 2306 is the contract dated September 7, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Contract No. 2306 referred to in this letter is the companytract dated September 7, 1955, involved in this dispute.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds contract dated September 7, 1955 is non-transferable specific delivery contract, hence illegal under notification.

holdings.text: The dispute whether the contract dated September 7, 1955 is illegal and void is not one which the arbitrators are competent to decide under cl. 14 and the respondents are entitled to maintain the application under s. 33 of the Arbitration Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are accordingly of the opinion that the dispute that the contract dated September 7, 1955, is illegal and void is number one which the arbitrators are companypetent to decide under cl. 14 and that inconsequence the respondents are entitled to maintain the present application under s. 33 of the Arbitration Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitration clause is integral part of contract; if contract void ab initio for illegality, clause perishes; follows Heyman v Darwins Ltd and Indian precedents like Union of India v Kishorilal Gupta.

holdings.text: The respondents are not estopped from questioning the validity of the award by reason of having submitted to the jurisdiction of the arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore Unable to accept the contention of Mr. Sanyal, that the respondents are estopped by their conduct from questioning the validity of the award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquiescence does not confer jurisdiction where no valid arbitration agreement exists; distinguishes Ex p Wyld as there was valid submission unaffected by formality.

holdings.text: The contract dated September 7, 1955 is a non-transferable specific delivery contract within s. 2(f) of the Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act.

anchor.surface_text: The contract with which we are concerned in these appeals was entered into on September 7, 1955, when the notification aforesaid was in force, and so it would be hit by it, unless it is a non-transferable specific delivery contract and the point for decision is whether it is that.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dispute it is specific delivery; rights not assignable due to import licence conditions prohibiting transfer and sale; contract terms construed with licence and circumstances confirm non-transferability of rights; liabilities generally non-transferable.

holdings.text: The contract dated September 7, 1955 is not illegal as it does not fall within the prohibition of the notification dated October 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: We may now proceed to consider the question whether the contract dated September 7, 1955, is illegal as falling within the prohibition enacted in the notification of the Central Government dated October 29, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification under s.17 prohibits forward contracts other than non-transferable specific delivery contracts; since contract is non-transferable specific delivery, exempted under s.18(1).

holdings.text: Rights and liabilities under the contract dated September 7, 1955 are not transferable.

anchor.surface_text: As it is only a benefit under a contract that can be assigned, the discussion really centres round two questions, are the buyers entitled to assign their right to got the goods on payment of price ? And are the sellers entitled to assign their right to receive the price on delivery of the goods ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Buyers' rights non-assignable per import licence terms (non-transferable, actual user only); sellers' rights non-assignable per contract terms (cl.3 shipping documents, delivery at mill) construed with licence and course of business indicating parties' understanding of non-transferability.

holdings.text: The word 'or' in s.2(f) defining non-transferable specific delivery contract as one where rights or liabilities are not transferable cannot be read as 'and'.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain meaning of 'or'; notification distinguishes transferable/non-transferable to serve purpose; no need for harmonious construction to alter text.

holdings.text: Terms of non-transferability can be implied from contract read as whole and surrounding circumstances even without express prohibition clause.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract construction permits implying terms from words used and legitimate surrounding circumstances like import licence; follows Virjee Daya Co. v. Ramakrishna Rice oil Mills.
